publicwhip.spmotion: *S2M-2100# Des McNulty: World AIDS Day 2004—That the Parliament acknowledges the importance of World AIDS Day on 1 December 2004, both for Scotland and for all those nations and peoples most affected by the spread of HIV/AIDS; notes that this year’s theme, "Have you heard me today?", seeks to raise awareness about, and help address, the many issues affecting women and girls around HIV and AIDS; notes the appropriateness of the first female Moderator of the Church of Scotland, Dr Alison Elliot, coming to the Parliament to address the Cross-Party International Development Group and the Cross-Party Group on Sexual Health on "Women, Girls and HIV/AIDS" on 15 December 2004; welcomes the continuing interest of the churches, agencies and other civic society bodies in Scotland which, over the past year, have highlighted the plight of people living with HIV/AIDS in sub-Saharan Africa, Scotland and elsewhere, and encourages all relevant agencies, the Scottish Executive and MSPs to continue to raise awareness about the disease and work towards its global eradication. Supported by: Susan Deacon*, Donald Gorrie*

S2M-2100# Des McNulty: World AIDS Day 2004—That the Parliament acknowledges the importance of World AIDS Day on 1 December 2004, both for Scotland and for all those nations and peoples most affected by the spread of HIV/AIDS; notes that this year’s theme, "Have you heard me today?", seeks to raise awareness about, and help address, the many issues affecting women and girls around HIV and AIDS; notes the appropriateness of the first female Moderator of the Church of Scotland, Dr Alison Elliot, coming to the Parliament to address the Cross-Party International Development Group and the Cross-Party Group on Sexual Health on "Women, Girls and HIV/AIDS" on 15 December 2004; welcomes the continuing interest of the churches, agencies and other civic society bodies in Scotland which, over the past year, have highlighted the plight of people living with HIV/AIDS in sub-Saharan Africa, Scotland and elsewhere, and encourages all relevant agencies, the Scottish Executive and MSPs to continue to raise awareness about the disease and work towards its global eradication. Supported by: Susan Deacon, Donald Gorrie, Marlyn Glen*, Jackie Baillie*
